title: What is Leukemia?
description: Understand what leukemia is and how it begins in your blood cells.

questions.questionText: Leukemia is a cancer that primarily affects which part of the body?
questions.explanation: Leukemia is a cancer of blood-forming tissues, including the bone marrow and lymphatic system. It results in the overproduction of abnormal white blood cells.

questions.questionText: Leukemia is contagious and can spread from person to person.
questions.explanation: Leukemia is NOT contagious. It is caused by genetic mutations in blood cells, not by viruses or bacteria that can be transmitted between people.

questions.questionText: Which type of blood cell does leukemia most commonly affect?
questions.explanation: Leukemia typically involves white blood cells (leukocytes). The name 'leukemia' comes from the Greek words for 'white' and 'blood'.

questions.questionText: Where are blood cells produced in the human body?
questions.explanation: Blood cells are produced in the bone marrow — the spongy tissue inside bones. In leukemia, this process goes wrong and abnormal cells are made.

questions.questionText: Leukemia only affects elderly people.
questions.explanation: Leukemia can affect people of all ages. Acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL) is actually the most common cancer in children.

title: Types of Leukemia
description: Learn the four main types of leukemia and how they differ.

questions.questionText: Which type of leukemia is most common in children?
questions.explanation: Acute Lymphocytic Leukemia (ALL) is the most common type of leukemia in children, accounting for about 75% of childhood leukemia cases.

questions.questionText: What does 'acute' mean in the context of leukemia?
questions.explanation: 'Acute' leukemia progresses rapidly and requires immediate treatment. 'Chronic' leukemia progresses more slowly.

questions.questionText: Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL) is the most common leukemia in adults.
questions.explanation: CLL is indeed the most common leukemia in adults in Western countries, primarily affecting people over 60.

questions.questionText: CML stands for:
questions.explanation: CML (Chronic Myeloid Leukemia) involves myeloid cells and typically progresses slowly. It is associated with the Philadelphia chromosome mutation.

questions.questionText: How many main types of leukemia are there?
questions.explanation: There are 4 main types: ALL (Acute Lymphocytic), AML (Acute Myeloid), CLL (Chronic Lymphocytic), and CML (Chronic Myeloid).

title: Early Warning Signs
description: Recognize the early symptoms of leukemia that you should never ignore.

questions.questionText: Which of these is a common early sign of leukemia?
questions.explanation: Extreme fatigue is one of the most common symptoms of leukemia. It occurs because leukemia cells crowd out healthy red blood cells that carry oxygen.

questions.questionText: Easy bruising or bleeding can be a symptom of leukemia.
questions.explanation: Yes. Leukemia reduces the number of platelets (clotting cells), which can lead to easy bruising, prolonged bleeding from cuts, or tiny red spots on the skin (petechiae).

questions.questionText: Why do leukemia patients often get frequent infections?
options: Abnormal white blood cells can't fight infections properly
questions.correctAnswer: Abnormal white blood cells can't fight infections properly
questions.explanation: Although leukemia produces too many white blood cells, these cells are abnormal and cannot fight infections effectively, leaving patients vulnerable.

questions.questionText: Swollen lymph nodes, especially in the neck, are a warning sign of:
questions.explanation: Swollen, painless lymph nodes can indicate leukemia cells have spread to the lymphatic system. Always have persistent swelling checked by a doctor.

questions.questionText: Night sweats and unexplained fever are symptoms that should be checked for leukemia.
questions.explanation: Persistent fever and night sweats (without infection) can be signs of leukemia. The body is reacting to the overproduction of abnormal blood cells.

title: When to See a Doctor
description: Know when to seek medical help and what tests doctors use to diagnose leukemia.

questions.questionText: Which blood test is typically the first step in diagnosing leukemia?
questions.explanation: A CBC measures the number of different blood cells. Abnormal levels of white blood cells, red blood cells, or platelets may suggest leukemia.

questions.questionText: A bone marrow biopsy is needed to definitively diagnose leukemia.
questions.explanation: A bone marrow biopsy involves removing a small sample of bone marrow to examine under a microscope. It's essential for confirming leukemia diagnosis and determining the type.

questions.questionText: How long should symptoms persist before seeing a doctor?
options: A few weeks of unexplained symptoms warrants a visit
Only if you have a family history
questions.correctAnswer: A few weeks of unexplained symptoms warrants a visit
questions.explanation: If you experience unexplained fatigue, bruising, fever, or swollen lymph nodes for more than 2 weeks, see a doctor. Early detection significantly improves outcomes.

questions.questionText: Which specialist typically treats leukemia?
questions.explanation: A hematologist specializes in blood diseases, and an oncologist treats cancer. Often a hematologist-oncologist handles leukemia treatment.

questions.questionText: Early detection of leukemia generally leads to better treatment outcomes.
questions.explanation: Absolutely. Early-stage leukemia often responds better to treatment. For example, childhood ALL has a 90%+ survival rate when caught and treated early.

title: Risk Factors Explained
description: Discover the genetic and environmental factors that increase leukemia risk.

questions.questionText: Which genetic condition significantly increases leukemia risk?
questions.explanation: People with Down syndrome (trisomy 21) have 10-20 times higher risk of developing leukemia, particularly ALL and AML.

questions.questionText: Exposure to high levels of radiation can increase the risk of leukemia.
questions.explanation: High-dose radiation exposure (such as from atomic bomb radiation or certain cancer treatments) is a known risk factor for developing leukemia, particularly AML.

questions.questionText: Which chemical exposure is linked to increased leukemia risk?
questions.explanation: Long-term exposure to benzene (found in cigarette smoke and some industrial settings) is a known risk factor for AML and other blood cancers.

questions.questionText: Smoking cigarettes increases the risk of developing leukemia.
questions.explanation: Cigarette smoke contains benzene and other carcinogens that can damage bone marrow DNA. Smokers have about twice the risk of developing AML compared to non-smokers.

questions.questionText: Having a family member with leukemia:
options: Has no effect on your risk
Makes it impossible for you to get it
questions.explanation: Most leukemia is not inherited, but having a sibling or parent with certain types (especially CLL) does slightly increase risk. Most people with risk factors never develop leukemia.

title: Chemotherapy Basics
description: Understand how chemotherapy works against leukemia and what to expect.

questions.questionText: What is the main goal of chemotherapy in leukemia treatment?
options: Kill or stop abnormal cancer cells from growing
questions.correctAnswer: Kill or stop abnormal cancer cells from growing
questions.explanation: Chemotherapy uses drugs to kill rapidly dividing cancer cells or stop them from multiplying. In leukemia, it targets the abnormal white blood cells.

questions.questionText: Chemotherapy only affects cancer cells and has no impact on healthy cells.
questions.explanation: Unfortunately, chemotherapy also affects fast-growing healthy cells (like hair follicles, gut lining), which causes side effects like hair loss and nausea.

questions.questionText: What does 'remission' mean in leukemia treatment?
options: No signs of cancer are detectable
questions.correctAnswer: No signs of cancer are detectable
questions.explanation: Remission means that cancer signs are no longer detectable through tests. Complete remission is a major treatment goal, though monitoring continues.

questions.questionText: How is chemotherapy most commonly administered in leukemia?
questions.explanation: Most leukemia chemotherapy is given intravenously so it can reach cancer cells throughout the bloodstream and bone marrow. Some drugs are also given orally.

questions.questionText: Targeted therapy is a newer, more precise treatment that attacks specific cancer cell markers.
questions.explanation: Targeted therapies (like imatinib for CML) work by targeting specific proteins or genes in cancer cells, causing fewer side effects than traditional chemotherapy.

title: Supporting Someone with Leukemia
description: Learn how to provide meaningful support to those fighting leukemia.

questions.questionText: What is the most important thing you can offer someone with leukemia?
questions.explanation: Simply being present, listening without judgment, and showing consistent care is what most patients value most. You don't need to have all the answers.

questions.questionText: Visiting a leukemia patient who is immunocompromised when you have a cold is safe.
questions.explanation: Leukemia patients, especially during chemotherapy, have weakened immune systems. Even a mild cold can be dangerous for them. Always check before visiting when sick.

questions.questionText: How can you practically help a leukemia patient?
options: Help with meals, transport to appointments, or errands
Tell them what treatment to choose
Avoid visiting to not disturb them
questions.correctAnswer: Help with meals, transport to appointments, or errands
questions.explanation: Practical help like cooking meals, driving to appointments, or handling errands reduces patient stress significantly and allows them to focus on healing.

questions.questionText: Caregivers of leukemia patients also need to take care of their own mental health.
questions.explanation: Caregiver burnout is real. Taking care of your own emotional and physical health allows you to provide better, sustainable support to your loved one.

questions.questionText: Which organization provides global support resources for leukemia patients?
questions.explanation: The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society (LLS) provides financial assistance, education, and support services for blood cancer patients and their families worldwide.
